guiding_questions: How were most societies organized in the 1700s?
Who held power in the 1700s? Why?
What was the divine right of kings?
overview: Students begin the course with a survey of the world in 1750, analyzing how societies were organized just before the revolutionary period [3]. This era is characterized as the **very end of the premodern world** [4].

details: Most states and empires were governed by a **single leader** (king, tsar, sultan, emperor, shah, or prince) who typically came from a **dynasty** [4]. The ruler’s legitimacy was often derived from birth and supported by religious and political elites [4].

Most emperors claimed they were **chosen or blessed by divine power** and ruled on behalf of God to maintain justice and order [4]. The question 'What was the divine right of kings?' helps students analyze the nature of monarchic governments [4]. For example, King James I’s 1610 speech to Parliament is used to illustrate how kings articulated their perceived divine inspiration and godlike power [5, 31].

Customs of social order were generally **hierarchical**, meaning people were fundamentally unequal. Dynasties and elite groups protected their **wealth and privilege** through force and propaganda, usually resisting sharing power with lower social groups [5].

Students analyze maps of the major **gunpowder empires** (Qing China, Mughal India, Ottoman Empire, Safavid Persia, Spain, France, England), as well as global trade routes (Atlantic World, Pacific/Indian Ocean, and world trade systems) and colonial holdings [3].
